body:
Hi we did a test with 10 routers and qtox ( windows ) killed 6 out of 10 routers . We had to  disable udp to make it work, which brings the questions , is the implementation of hole-punching correct ? How do other programs holepunch without killing the (same) routers. Why do we need udp holepunching when it could first try to upnp ? The router list includes tplink netgear ZTE  thomson and others ( common routers where I live).

At least you could default udp off for now since I cant even recommend it to somone without have to be like " Oh and you need to go uncheck that udp thing... "

Many thanks,
Lait

comment_data.body:
> At least you could default udp off for now 

That's a client setting. You should also open this issue with your client of choice.
True, the default setting is up to the qtox program. But the UDP that kills the routers is in the toxcore.
There is preliminary uPNP support in the irungentoo/new branch. Perhaps it would make sense to make a pull request with those patches.

laietana: Yes our country main cable ISP uses Thompson routers too for internet and for connecting IPTV box behind router. Seems like massive connection count especially in UDP mode causes routers to go mad and freeze. Personally i use 99% TCP mode and only switch temporary UDP ON when transferring large files to get direct connection.

@fcore117 are you talking about internet routers? Or home based wifi and/or
internet sharing devices (commonly called routers, even though 'NAT Hub' is
often a much better name)?

On Mon, Oct 17, 2016 at 4:05 AM, fcore117 notifications@github.com wrote:

> laietana: Yes our country main cable ISP uses Thompson routers too for
> internet and for connecting IPTV box behind router. Seems like massive
> connection count especially in UDP mode causes routers to go mad and freeze.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/issues/195#issuecomment-254178065,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAO20Gw-Es_2qN8OzKQWPI-G7lJet4YUks5q01Z-gaJpZM4KW4fD
> .
GrayHatter: thomson tg784, Thomson ST780WL, Thomson tg789vn, Inteno DG301A, zte models and similar are most used of adsl routers around here.

Who wants to make a PR cherry-picking the uPNP code from https://github.com/irungentoo/toxcore/commits/new? Look for "Commits on Mar 21, 2016", there are a few related commits. Perhaps @Ansa89 can do it?
@iphydf I was talking with @cleverca22 on IRC, and IIRC the conclusion we came to was that UPnP would certainly help with this, it wouldn't solve the issue by itself.
i agree upnp is different topic as it wont help with connection count but helps to create direct connection easily if router has upnp support enabled.
We now have an option: `hole_punching_enabled`. You can set it to `false` by calling `tox_options_set_hole_punching_enabled(options, false);`. Does that help?
Affects qTox users: https://github.com/qTox/qTox/issues/4249 , disabling UDP helps.

rename.to: UDP hole punching incompatible with cheap hardware routers

labels.description: Bug fix for the user, not a fix to a build script
labels.name: bug

title: UDP hole punching incompatible with cheap hardware routers
